comments:
I am using Eclipse 3.3M3 on a Mac Pro (Intel) with MacOSX 10.4.8 and I am not able to create a new Java project. On starting up Eclipse I see the following error in the error log:

Invalid value for org.eclipse.ui/initialFastViewBarLocation preference.  Value "" should be one of "left", "bottom", or "right".

No exception stacktrace is available according to the error info.

This prevents me from creating a new Java project. Thus:

1. Choose File->New->Project shows the New Project wizard
2. Open the Java folder and click on "Java Project"
3. Now click the Next button to advance the wizard to the next step

This fails and a NPE is thrown. Stacktrace:

eclipse.buildId=I20061102-1715
java.version=1.5.0_06
java.vendor=Apple Computer, Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=macosx, ARCH=x86, WS=carbon, NL=en_US

JavaCore.getOption(JavaCore.COMPILER_COMPLIANCE) returns null, which indicates
that the platform has not been started properly (preferences are not properly
initalized.)

Moving to Platform/UI to see where the "Invalid value for
org.eclipse.ui/initialFastViewBarLocation" message comes from.

This comes from the initialization code that places the fast view bar on startup. 

It simtply logs the message and returns a valid value so I doubt if it's part of the NPE (but is an indication that the preference store is corrupt in some way...).

Timothy, is this a vanilla 3.3M3 eclipse (i.e. no funky overrides...)?

(In reply to comment #2)
> This comes from the initialization code that places the fast view bar on
> startup. 
> 
> It simtply logs the message and returns a valid value so I doubt if it's part
> of the NPE (but is an indication that the preference store is corrupt in some
> way...).
> 
> Timothy, is this a vanilla 3.3M3 eclipse (i.e. no funky overrides...)?

Hello Eric,

Yes I downloaded and installed Eclipse 3.3M3. I upgrade my renaming my existing eclipse folder to say eclipse-3.3M2 and then adding the untarred folder named eclipse to /Applications. Tried to create a new project for some files brought over from a project created on a PC (source and class files only) and this problem was seen.

Tried restarting Eclipse but same result. Also tried trashing eclipse folder and re-untarring again with no change.

Timothy, I can't see any causal link between the log entry regarding the FVB and the failure of the New Project wizard...so here are some more querstions...;-).

Are you using a new workspace or an existing one?

If you're using an existing one could you search its '.metadata' for "initialFastViewBarLocation" in any XML file and send me the value if found?

Is this a regression? (i.e. can you do this in M2 or 3.1 with the same steps)

BTW, this has to be something local to your setup because this is the only instance I've seen of this defect (Markus, have you seen dups of this?) and I'd ahve expected to see a Bugzilla flood if it was a common circumstance...

When I install Eclipse afresh it of course prompts for the workspace directory on first startup. I choose my main dev root folder as the workspace folder, so I am using an existing workspace.

I searched for the string "initialFastViewBarLocation" in terminal with:

fgrep -Ri initialFastViewBarLocation .metadata

Found only entries in the .log thus:

.metadata/.log:!MESSAGE Invalid value for org.eclipse.ui/initialFastViewBarLocation preference.  Value "" should be one of "left", "bottom", or "right".

And yes this is a regression as I tested with Eclipse 3.2 and creating a new Java project in the wizard works fine.

(In reply to comment #5)
>
> I'm experiencing the same problems under Debian OS.  I'm using 3.2.0, dl'ed
> from Yoxos with the Java and C/C++ plugins.  I just untarred their package and
> started using it.  Error code follows.
> 
And I'm having the same problem on Kubuntu, Feisty Fawn, running 3.2.0.  As for the other guy, downloaded, untarred, ran... and got the error.  Stack trace is damn near the same too.

Workaround:
Create an ordinary project and then apply a 'Java' nature to it.

Cheers.
Pete, which eclipse build are you running on?

(In reply to comment #8)
> Pete, which eclipse build are you running on?
> 
Its the basic SDK download from eclipse.org.  Version is actually 3.2.2 (not 3.2.0 as previously stated, typed it in wrong, oops...).

Build ID: M20070212-1330

Cheers,

P.

Have (or can?) any of you tell whether or not this issue still exists? I can't repro it on 3.3M3 or 3.2 (haven't checked 3.2.2 but it's unlikely that we'd fix it there anyway).

Given that this is one of the most-used code flows I'd have expected to be flooded with dup's if this was a common failure...
Yes, this is still present.  I only installed Eclipse on the laptop a few days ago.

Peter, I can't repro this...is this a clean workspace or are you opening an existing, older one? Do you have anything except the eclipse SDK loaded?

Given the traceback what happens if you explicitly define the JVM you're using via the '-vm <vm path>\jre\bin\java.exe' option on your startup?
Would somebody on JDT land comment on this?

Go to Window>Preferences>Java>Installed JREs
- Do you have any JREs installed?

Try to start with the vm option as eric suggests
- Still no JRE?

Second trace is because JavaRuntime.getDefaultVMInstall() returns 'null'. The reason for the first one may be that debug could not/did not set a default compliance because there is no default vm install (org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JavaRuntime.initializeVMs())
We should maybe show a dialog to tell the user to first configure a JVM.

Created an attachment (id=69233)
fix

This is a minimal fix:
 Show error on new java project wizard and offer link to jre preference page

However, since I can't reproduce this I don't know how to test it.

Created an attachment (id=69292)
fix

Even smaller fix
Filed bug 190161 against jdt/debug for the COMPILER_COMPLIANCE issue.

Created an attachment (id=69491)
fix

With this fix:
- NPE is prevented
- A warning with a link to the JRE page is shown if no default jvm install
- It is still possible to create the project even without a jvm install
patch is good. Markus, can you review?
+1 for 3.3 RC3, patch released > 20070531

verified in I20070601-0010

The code has been released. 

Timothy, Mike or Peter, can you confirm that this works for you?

Can't verify the fix (sorry I'm not hooked up to the eclipse, but can confirm it was the lack of default JRE.  I'd previously only ever installed on Windows, where this hadn't been a problem.

The patch is obviously a good idea, but can I suggest maybe upgrading the installation instructions for the SDK download as well, to indicate that you need to point it to the JRE manually.
that would be, I'm not hooked up to the eclipse repository...

>that would be, I'm not hooked up to the eclipse repository...
Just go to the download page and download the latest build (RC3 is going to be there in a few hours).

Yep, fix is good.

Thanks for the quick turnaround guys.

(In reply to comment #23)
> The patch is obviously a good idea, but can I suggest maybe upgrading the
> installation instructions for the SDK download as well, to indicate that you
> need to point it to the JRE manually.
> 

Where do I find this instruction? Hint that usualy it is not necessary to point to the JRE manually as eclipse is able to detect JREs automaticaly. I don't know why it did not work for you guys.
